newsitem.title: USA: White House rejects critique of new code policy.
newsitem.headline: White House rejects critique of new code policy.

text.p: The Clinton administration rejected on Thursday criticism from 20 U.S. legislators of its new policy to relax export restrictions on computer encoding technology.
The legislators, Democrats and Republicans, sent a letter to the administration this week attacking the new policy as probably unworkable and needlessly restrictive.
"If you look, there is a critical mass of industry that is working with the federal government to develop this system," Heidi Kukis, a spokeswoman in Vice President Al Gore's office said.

Under the administration policy announced Oct 1, U.S. companies could export powerful encryption programs only if the programs included a feature known as key recovery to allow the government to read encoded messages.
"The policy has always been based on the fact that development of a key recovery system will be market driven," Kukis said.
After the administration unveiled its new policy, a number of prominent hardware firms led by International Business Machines Corp formed a consortium to propagate key recovery systems.
Software firms and online services have opposed key recovery, however.
In the last session of Congress, legislators introduced several bills to relax U.S. export laws without requiring key recovery features, but the measures did not pass.
Kukis pointedly rejected one charge in the letter and repeated in a press release from Sen. Ron Wyden concerning the administration's new policy.
The Oregon Democrat and the letter said the Clinton policy granted the Federal Bureau of Investigation "veto power" over applications for exporting encryption programs.
"Wyden's statement is incorrect," Kukis said. "The FBI does not and will not have veto power over dual use encryption exports. It's irresponsible to suggest that they would."

Rather, the FBI will have a seat on a committee to review export applications along with the departments of Defense, Commerce, State, Energy and Justice and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Kukis said.
"The only person who will have veto power is the President himself," she said.
